docs.lead_paragraph: The High Court ruled Monday that the government had coerced three women infected with H.I.V. to agree to be sterilized after giving birth, the Southern Africa Litigation Center said.

headline.main: Namibia: Court Says Government Coerced Women Into Sterilization
headline.print_headline: Namibia: Court Says Government Coerced Women Into Sterilization

docs.abstract: Namibian High Court rules that the government had coerced three women infected with HIV to agree to be sterilized after giving birth; the three women who brought the case will be awarded monetary damages, but the amounts have not been fixed.
docs.snippet: The High Court ruled Monday that the government had coerced three women infected with H.I.V. to agree to be sterilized after giving birth, the Southern Africa Litigation Center said.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state’s ban on abortions starting at 20 weeks of pregnancy is poised to take effect this week after a federal judge ruled Monday that the new law is constitutional.

headline.main: Arizona: Judge Upholds 20-Week Limit on Abortions
headline.print_headline: Arizona: 20-Week Limit Is Upheld for Abortions

docs.abstract: Arizona's ban on abortions starting at 20 weeks of pregnancy is poised to take effect after Judge James Teilborg of United States District Court rules that the new law is constitutional.
docs.snippet: The state’s ban on abortions starting at 20 weeks of pregnancy is poised to take effect this week after a federal judge ruled Monday that the new law is constitutional.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite its many delights, summer also brings its fair share of pestilence. One, called babesiosis, has only recently been widely recognized as a potentially serious outdoor hazard. According to a very detailed study conducted on Block Island, R.I., it could eventually rival Lyme disease as the most common tick-borne ailment in the United States. But with reasonable precautions, neither babesiosis nor Lyme should keep you from enjoying a romp in the grass or hike in the woods.

headline.main: Personal Health: Another Reason to Guard Against Ticks

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column warns of the growing dangers posed by babesiosis, which could eventually rival Lyme disease as the most common tick-borne ailment in the United States; provides advice on how to avoid infection. Drawing (M)l

docs.lead_paragraph: The older a woman is when she gives birth, the lower her risk for endometrial cancer, a new study reports. A large team of researchers, led by V. Wendy Setiawan, an assistant professor of preventive medicine at the University of Southern California, pooled data from 17 studies that included 8,671 cases of endometrial cancer and 16,562 controls. After adjusting for known risks, the researchers found that women who had their last babies after age 40 had a 44 percent reduced risk of endometrial cancer, compared with women who had their babies before age 25.

headline.main: Vital Signs | Patterns: Later Pregnancy, Lower Risk of a Cancer

docs.abstract: Dr V Wendy Setiawan study in The American Journal of Epidemiology finds that the older a woman is when she gives birth, the lower her risk for endometrial cancer. (M)

headline.main: Behind the Cover Story: Suzy Hansen on Improving Health in Mississippi, the Iran Way

docs.abstract: The author of this week's cover article answers questions on the uphill battle of preventive medicine, what health workers have learned from Iran, and how poverty in Mississippi is not what you'd expect.

docs.lead_paragraph: A custody battle “between two diametrically opposed worldviews on parentage and family” touches on contentious social and legal questions over what happens to children when civil unions dissolve.

headline.seo: A Civil Union Ends in an Abduction and Questions
headline.main: Which Mother for Isabella? Civil Union Ends in an Abduction and Questions
headline.print_headline: Which Mother for Isabella? Civil Union Ends in an Abduction and Questions

docs.abstract: Custody battle between Lisa A Miller and Janet Jenkins over their daughter Isabella Miller-Jenkins embodies some of America's bitterest culture wars; Miller, a born-again convert to conservative Christianity who has denounced lesbianism as an addiction, is wanted by the FBI and Interpol for kidnapping Isabella and fleeing to Nicaragua after custody was granted to Jenkins, with whom she'd had a civil union.
docs.snippet: A custody battle “between two diametrically opposed worldviews on parentage and family” touches on contentious social and legal questions over what happens to children when civil unions dissolve.

keywords.value: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

headline.main: Who Made That Home Pregnancy Test?

docs.abstract: Home pregnancy tests first appeared in drugstores in 1977, but did not gain widespread popularity until the test came in a wand form in 1988.
